metadata.title: Stable Cu-Ni/SiO<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf> catalysts prepared by using citric acid-assisted impregnation for vapor-phase hydrogenation of levulinic acid

Fig. 3 Fig. 4 TG profiles of 6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 samples reduced at 300 °C. (a) NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300, (b) CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300, (c) CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-400, (d) CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500, and (e) CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-600. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XRD patterns of (a) NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300 reduced at 300 °C, (b) NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300 used in the reaction for 8 h, (c) CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500 reduced at 300 °C, and (d) CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500 used in the reaction for 8 h. The samples used in the reaction were the same as those in Table 1 and Fig. S2. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Change in conversion of LA over (a) NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300 and (b) CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500. Reaction conditions: H2 flow rate, 30 cm3 min−1; catalyst weight, 0.25 g; reaction temperature, 250 °C; WHSV, 6.6 h−1. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 XRF spectra of (a) fresh NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300, (b) NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300 used for the reaction for 24 h, (c) fresh CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500, and (d) CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500 used for the reaction for 68 h. Stable Cu-Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by using citric acid-assisted impregnation for vapor-phase hydrogenation of levulinic acid Rei Yoshida a Daolai Sun a b Yasuhiro Yamada a Satoshi Sato a ⁎ a Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, Chiba, 263-8522, Japan Graduate School of Engineering Chiba University Chiba 263-8522 Japan b School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin, 300130, China School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Hebei University of Technology Tianjin 300130 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Cu-Ni/SiO2 catalyst was developed by impregnation assisted with citric acid for the vapor-phase hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (GVL). The prepared catalysts were characterized by using X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscope (TEM), temperature-programed reduction, thermogravimetry analysis, and X-ray fluorescence analysis. The XRD analysis and the TEM observation of the catalyst samples indicate that the usage of citric acid in the preparation process of impregnation improved the dispersion of Cu and Ni metal on SiO2. A Cu-Ni/SiO2 catalyst with Cu loading of 4 wt.% and Ni of 16 wt.% showed the best performance in the hydrogenation of LA to GVL under ambient H2 pressure at a high weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 13.2 h−1 and 250 °C: the conversion was 98.2% and the GVL selectivity was 97.6%. The catalyst prepared by citric acid-assisted impregnation showed the resistance to catalyst deactivation. Keywords Levulinic acid γ-Valerolactone Citric acid Cu-Ni bimetallic catalyst Stable activity 1 Introduction The amount of CO2 emission has been increasing, so that a sustainable society is strongly required. Recently, lignocellulosic biomass, which is composed of lignin, cellulose, and hemicellulose [1], is attractive as a potential alternative energy resource to fossil fuel due to its sustainability. Levulinic acid (LA) is one of the chemicals which can be produced from cellulose and hemicellulose [2,3]. LA is a platform molecule to produce various materials such as γ-valerolactone (GVL) [4–6], α-, β-, γ-angelica lactones (ALs) [7], ethyl levulinate [8,9], δ-aminolevulinic acid [10], and 2-methyltetrahydrofuran [11]. Among these chemicals, GVL is a useful chemical because of its wide application as solvent [12], food additive [13], and an intermediate of gasoline, biodiesel, jet fuel [14–16], and polymers [16–19]. Many reports related to the hydrogenation of LA to GVL over noble metal catalysts have been reported [16,19]. In contrast to noble metals, non-noble catalysts have an advantage of the low cost for industrial application. Among non-noble metal catalysts, Ni- and Cu-based catalysts have been reported for vapor-phase hydrogenation of LA to GVL. Ni-based catalysts such as Ni/ZSM-5, Ni/SiO2, and Ni/TiO2 showed the GVL productivity of 0.91, 0.87 and 0.58 kgGVL kgcat. −1 h−1 under ambient H2 pressure conditions at 250, 250, and 270 °C, respectively [20–22]. A Cu-based catalyst such as Cu/Al2O3 shows the GVL productivity of 0.14 kgGVL kgcat. −1 h−1 under ambient H2 pressure conditions at 265 °C [23], and Cu/SiO2 shows the GVL productivity of 0.51 kgGVL kgcat. −1 h−1 at an H2 pressure of 10 bar at 265 °C [5]. A Cu-Ni/SiO2 with a weight ratio of Cu/Ni/SiO2 = 60/20/20 shows the GVL productivity 0.49 kgGVL kgcat. −1 h−1 for 100 h by using formic acid instead of hydrogen [24]. We have recently reported that high GVL productivity of 1.64 kgGVL kgcat. −1 h−1 is obtained over a SiO2-supported Cu-Ni catalyst with a Cu of 6 wt.% and a Ni of 14 wt.% at a WHSV of 6.6 h−1 and 250 °C for 50 h [25]. All Cu-Ni/SiO2 with different Cu/Ni ratios show high GVL selectivity, while the catalysts with low Cu/Ni ratios show high conversion. In addition, Ni has an ability to inhibit carbon accumulation, and Cu has an ability to inhibit the decomposition of LA. SiO2 without metals can catalyze the selective formation of ALs from LA in an N2 atmosphere [7]. Thus, GVL can be produced through ALs as an intermediate in the hydrogenation of LA catalyzed by Cu-Ni/SiO2 in an H2 atmosphere [25]. Scheme 1 is proposed as a probable reaction route in the vapor-phase hydrogenation of LA to GVL in our group. Generally, metal dispersion affects the catalytic activity, and the catalyst with high metal dispersion occasionally exhibits significant catalytic activity. Zhang et al. have reported that chelating reagents such as citric acid and ethylene diamine have an effect -on promoting Ni dispersion for Ni/SBA-15 [26]. Moreover, in a catalyst preparation, citric acid has a high ability to mix two components at relatively low calcination temperatures. For example, solid solution of NiO-MgO is readily formed through a molten mixture of metal nitrates with citric acid followed by calcination at 500 °C [27]. In this study, we investigated the effect of citric acid on the catalyst preparation of Cu-Ni/SiO2 in an impregnation method to improve metal dispersion on SiO2. The catalytic activity and stability of the resulted Cu-Ni/SiO2 were examined in the vapor-phase hydrogenation of LA. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst samples SiO2 (CARiACT Q10 with mean pore diameters of 10 nm, SBET = 295 m2 g−1) was supplied by Fuji Silycia Chemical Ltd. Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O as the precursors of the corresponding metals as well as citric acid monohydrate were purchased from Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Japan. All Cu-Ni bimetallic catalysts were prepared by an impregnation method. Firstly, a solution with a certain amount of metal nitrate and prescribed amount of citric acid was prepared. Unless otherwise stated, the amount of added citric acid is the same as the total amount of Cu + Ni metals: the molar ratio of citric acid to Cu + Ni metals is 1. We have previously reported that Cu-Ni/SiO2 with 6 wt.% Cu and 14 wt.% Ni showed the highest catalytic performance [25]. Thus, in this paper, the total loading of Cu and Ni metals on SiO2 was fixed at 6 and 14 wt.%, respectively. Then, the solution was dropped onto a SiO2 support. The sample was illuminated by a 350-W electric light bulb, and water was evaporated at ca. 70 °C. Finally, the resulted sample was dried at 110 °C for 12 h and calcined at a prescribed temperature for 3 h. Prior to the catalytic reaction, the catalyst sample was reduced in H2 flow at a prescribed temperature for 1 h. Hereafter, the resulting catalysts are expressed as CA-xCu-yNi/SiO2-z, where x and y mean the weight percentage of the supported Cu and Ni metal, respectively, and z means the calcination temperature. In addition, NC-xCu-yNi/SiO2-z means the sample prepared by the impregnation method without using citric acid. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts The XRD patterns of the samples were recorded on a D8 ADVANCE (Bruker, Japan) using Cu Kα radiation. The thermogravimetry-differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) was performed using Thermoplus 8120E2 (Rigaku) under the conditions: a sample of ca. 10 mg was heated in air from a room temperature to 900 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. For the characterization of metal state of prepared catalyst, temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) was performed under the conditions: a sample of 30 mg was heated in a mixed gas of H2/N2 (=1/9) with the flow rate of 10 cm3 min−1 from a room temperature to 900 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. High-resolution field emission transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were observed on a Hitachi HF-2200 microscope operated at 200 kV. X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis was performed by using EDX-900HS (Shimadzu, Japan). 2.3 Vapor-phase hydrogenation of LA to GVL LA, which was purchased from Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Japan, was used for the catalytic reaction without further purification. Vapor-phase hydrogenation of LA was performed in a fixed-bed down-flow glass reactor (inner diameter, 17 mm; length, 49.4 mm). After a catalyst of 0.125 g had been reduced in the reactor at 300 °C for 1 h, the catalytic reaction of LA was performed at an ambient pressure of H2 and 250 °C. LA was fed through the reactor top at a liquid feed rate of 1.65 cm3 h−1 together with an H2 flow of 30 cm3 min−1. The products were collected in a dry ice-acetone trap at −78 °C every hour. Products in the effluent were identified by a gas chromatograph (GC, QP5050, Shimadzu, Japan) equipped with a mass-spectrometer. The products were quantitatively analyzed by a GC (GC-14B, Shimadzu, Japan) equipped with a flame ionization detector and a capillary column of Inert Cap 1 (0.25 mm I.D. and 60 m, GL-Science, Japan). 1-Butanol was used as an internal standard substance for the GC analysis. The conversion of reactant and the selectivity to each product were calculated as a molar percentage (mol.%). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the prepared catalysts We have previously reported that Cu-Ni/SiO2 with 6 wt.% Cu and 14 wt.% Ni showed the highest catalytic performance [25]. Thus, in the following section, the total loading of Cu and Ni in the bimetallic Cu-Ni/SiO2 catalyst was fixed at 6 and 14 wt.%, respectively. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500 and NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300 catalysts reduced at 300 °C. Diffraction peaks of Cu were observed at 43.5° and 50.4°, and those of Ni were observed at 44.5° and 51.8° in NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300 [25]. However, only a broad peak of NiO was observed at 43.6° and 37.4° [28] in CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500. Even after the reduction at 300 °C, metals in the sample were oxidized in air before XRD analysis. The broad peaks indicate that Ni and Cu metal particles were highly dispersed on CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500 rather than those on NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300, and that the fine particles readily re-oxidized in air. To clarify the metal particle size on the silica support, some reduced samples were observed with TEM analysis. Fig. 2 shows the TEM images of CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500 and NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300 as well as single metal catalysts such as NC-20Cu/SiO2-300 and NC-20Ni/SiO2-300. In the catalysts prepared without using citric acid such as NC-20Ni/SiO2-300, NC-20Cu/SiO2-300 and NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300, the metal particle size was in a range of 20–50 nm. In the case of CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2, however, the metal particle size was about 5 nm, which was obviously smaller than that of NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300. This result is consistent with a report of Zhang et al. [26], who have reported that the dispersion of Ni particle on a support is improved by adding chelating ligand into the impregnation solution. The size of Ni particles in Ni/SBA-15 is ca. 20 nm without using chelating reagents, while the sizes reduce to ca. 4, 4, and 6 nm for the chelating reagents such as citric acid, ethylene diamine, and acetic acid, respectively. Fig. 3 shows the TPR patterns of CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 calcined at different temperatures. Two reduction peaks were observed at 189 and 828 °C for CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300. The peaks at 189 and 828 °C are attributed to the reduction of simple metal oxides and Ni-silicate, respectively [29]. In NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300, the peak of Ni-silicate was not observed. This suggests that highly dispersed Ni by adding citric acid into impregnation solution produces Ni-silicate. In addition, a peak around 250 °C was observed in CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 catalyst calcined at 400°C while it appeared at around 270 and 310 °C in CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 calcined at 500 and 600 °C, respectively. CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 calcined at 400, 500 and 600 °C showed the peak around 250–310 °C, which was not observed in NC- and CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300. This peak is attributed to the aggregated NiO particle, and it gradually shifted to higher temperature as calcination temperature rises. The peak around 250–310 °C would be attributed to NiO aggregated with the rise in the calcination temperature. In TG curves of unreduced CA- and NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 (Fig. S1 in the supplementary information), a significant difference was observed between the samples. Weight change in CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 samples during TG process above 500 °C is larger than that of NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2. Although the difference in the weight change was as small as 0.15%, it clearly indicates that the sample prepared using citric acid has a small amount of carbon residuals originated from citric acid. Fig. 4 shows the TG curves of reduced CA- and NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2. Before TG analysis, all the samples were reduced in an H2 flow of 30 cm3 min−1 at 300 °C for 1 h in the same manner as the preheating prior to the reaction. In NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 sample, an increase in weight between 250 and 420 °C is attributed to the oxidation of metal species during the TG process. CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-600 also showed a relatively small weight increase in the same temperature range. This indicates that a part of metal species exists but rest of metal has been oxidized in air prior to TG analysis. In contrast, no such weight increase was observed in the CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 calcined at 300, 400, and 500 °C. This indicates that most of the metal species is readily reoxidized in air before TG analysis. Thus, the metal species would be highly dispersed in the samples, and the dispersion would be maintained by residual carbon derived from citric acid used in the preparation. Citric acid used in the preparation induces homogeneous immobilization of metal species and subsequent formation of fine metal nanoparticles. 3.2 Catalytic activity of CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 calcined at different temperatures The highly-dispersed bimetallic 6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 is expected to have a high catalytic performance in the conversion of LA. In order to clarify the difference in the catalytic performance, the catalytic reactions of LA were conducted at a high WHSV of 13.2 h−1 because the catalysts showed full conversion at a low WHSV. Table 1 summarizes the results of the catalytic reaction of LA at 250 °C over CA- and NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 calcined at different temperatures. They showed the changes in the conversion with time on stream under high WHSV conditions (Fig. S2), and the average conversion for the initial 8 h is presented in Table 1. In the comparison among the NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared without using citric acid, NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300 showed higher conversion than NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-400 and NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500. It is preferable that high calcination temperatures as 500 °C cause the aggregation of metal oxides, and that a low calcination temperature at 300 °C induces high dispersion of metal oxides without residual carbon originated from citric acid. However, in the catalysts prepared using citric acid, the effect of calcination temperature has a different trend: CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500 gave the highest conversion of 96.1% with GVL selectivity of 98.2%. This is because a low calcination temperature leads to excess citric acid-derived carbon on the catalysts, which inhibits the reaction. In contrast, the carbon would be removed from the catalyst at a high calcination temperature in CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-600, while the metal oxide precursors could be aggregated, as discussed in the Section 3.1. In comparison to NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300, CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500 showed a high LA conversion and a high GVL selectivity. It is obvious that this improvement of the catalytic activity would be affected by carbon residuals originated from citric acid used in the preparation. Fig. 5 shows the XRD patterns of CA- and NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 catalysts used in the hydrogenation of LA. In NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300, the intensity of the metal peaks increased after the reaction for 8 h, indicating that the metals on the catalysts aggregated during the reaction. In CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500, however, NiO diffraction peaks were transformed to those of Ni metals after the reaction. The particle size of metals is smaller than that of NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300 after the reaction. Thus, CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500 shows high LA conversion and high resistance to deactivation (Table 1 and Fig. S2). The carbon residuals would play an important role as a stabilizer of dispersed metal species on silica support. 3.3 Catalytic activity of CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 prepared at different citric acid contents and Cu/Ni ratios To clarify the effect of the amount of citric acid on the catalytic activity, 6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500 catalysts were prepared by using different amount of citric acid. Here, the sample is expressed as nCA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 where n is the molar ratio of citric acid to the total Cu + Ni metals in the preparation, and the calcination temperature was 500 °C. Table 2 summarizes the catalytic reaction of LA over 6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 prepared using different amounts of citric acid. Although all the catalysts showed a high GVL selectivity over 96.0%, the conversion changed with the amount of added citric acid. At a small amount of citric acid, 0.5CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 and 0.75CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 gave a conversion of 92.8 and 93.6%, respectively. These values were lower than the conversion over 1.0CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2, which is the same as CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500, and 1.25CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2. It is reasonable that, at the ratio of 0.75 or smaller, excess metals uncoordinated with citric acid would be aggregated to large particles. At the ratio of 1 or larger, high conversion was obtained, indicating that a citric acid needs to coordinate a metal ion at the molar ratio of 1. On the other hand, excess amount of citric acid such as 1.5CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 gave a low conversion of 92.2%. The TG curve of CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500 (Figs. 4 and S1) indicates that organic residuals still existed on the catalysts. Hence, the residual citric acid has a possibility of covering the metal surface. Consequently, an equimolar ratio of citric acid/metal or a little larger in the impregnation process provides the best dispersion of metals. Table 3 shows the results of the catalytic reaction of LA over CA-Cu-Ni/SiO2 with different Cu/Ni weight ratios. The calcination temperature was 500 °C. The reaction results have a similar trend to the previous reserch of NC-Cu-Ni/SiO2-300 [25]: catalysts at low Cu/Ni ratios showed high LA conversion. CA-2Cu-18Ni/SiO2, CA-4Cu-16Ni/SiO2, and CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 showed the conversion of 93.7%, 98.2% and 96.1% respectively. On the other hand, CA-14Cu-6Ni/SiO2 with a high Cu/Ni showed the relatively low conversion of 74.6%. In this reaction, since Ni is more active than Cu [25], the catalysts with low Cu/Ni ratios are effective. All the catalysts showed the high GVL selectivity. Over CA-4Cu-16Ni/SiO2, CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2, and CA-8Cu-12Ni/SiO2, the GVL selectivity was higher than 97%. However, CA-2Cu-18Ni/SiO2 showed GVL selectivity of 96.2%. Since Ni has the high catalytic ability of CC bond cleavage [30], catalysts with high Ni contents form many by-products through CC bond cleavage. In Table 3, CA-4Cu-16Ni/SiO2 showed the best catalytic performance with the highest GVL yield. In the previous research [25], NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 with a Cu/Ni ratio of 6/14 shows the best performance. This difference would appear due to the addition of citric acid. Since the interaction between Cu and Ni metal improves the catalyst activity for this reaction, the best Cu/Ni weight ratio was changed by improving the dispersion of the metals. It is reported that solid solution of NiO-MgO is readily formed by using citric acid after calcination at 500 °C [27]. It is probable that citric acid would play a role as a mixing reagent for different metals to improve the interaction between Ni and Cu. 3.4 Stability of CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 during a long-run catalytic reaction Fig. 6 shows the changes in the catalytic activity of CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500 with time on stream as well as NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300. Here, the reaction conditions are practical ones at WHSV of 6.6 h−1. Although both catalysts deactivated with time on stream, deactivation rates of the catalysts were different. The conversion of LA over NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300 decreased from 99.5 to 70.0% during 24 h. However, the conversion of LA over CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500 decreased from 99.8 to 95.5% during 24 h, and it decreased to 71.9% after 65 h-run. This difference could be caused by the stability of dispersed metal particles against aggregation. In order to investigate the difference of deactivation speed between CA- and NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2, the used catalysts were analyzed by XRF and TG analysis. From the results of TG (Fig. S3), the weight changes of NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 and CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 between fresh and the used catalysts were similar to each other: the difference is as small as 2%. Thus, the deposition of carbonaceous species during the reaction would not be the cause of the deactivation. On the other hand, the results of XRF analysis revealed a significant difference between NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 and CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2. Fig. 7 show the results of XRF spectra of fresh and used catalysts. For the reference, the components of Cu, Ni, and Si in the catalysts used for the reaction are summarized in Table S1. Peak intensity of Cu in the used NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300 was smaller than that of fresh one. This indicates that Cu could be leached from NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-300 during the reaction, or that metal particles including Ni and Cu could be significantly changed. Therefore, the deactivation of catalyst may be caused by the leaching of Cu species from the catalyst. In CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500, however, no significant change was observed in the XRF spectra of Ni and Cu between fresh and the used catalysts. Thus, the addition of citric acid to the impregnation solution possibly influences inhibiting the Cu metal leaching. In a liquid-phase hydrogenation of LA to GVL, leaching of Cu has been confirmed from Cu/Ni/hydrotalcite catalyst [31] as well as from Cu-ZrO2 [32]. Even in a vapor phase, a slight decrease in Cu species is observed in a deactivated Cu/Al2O3 catalyst by atomic adsorption analysis [23]. We speculate that citric acid plays an important role either as a binder of metals with silica support or as a mixing agent for Cu with Ni in addition to the enhancement of metal dispersion. Consequently, NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 could be deactivated by the leaching of Cu species as well as the aggregation of metal species, whereas CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 would be deactivated by the gradual aggregation of metals shown in Fig. 5. 3.5 Mechanistic consideration of GVL formation and model structure of metals over Cu-Ni/SiO2 In the hydrogenation of LA to GVL over 6Cu-14Ni/SiO2, there are two possible intermediates: ALs and 2-hydroxypentanoic acid. In an H2 atmosphere, GVL might be formed after the hydrogenation of keto function of LA followed by the intramolecular cyclization of 2-hydroxypentanoic acid. We have performed the LA conversion over CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 in N2 carrier gas to confirm the formation of ALs, as shown in Scheme 1. At 300 °C and WHSV = 6.8 h−1, selectivity to ALs was 91% at LA conversion of 37%. At 250 °C and WHSV = 18.5 h−1, high ALs selectivity of 96% was obtained at LA conversion of 6.7%. The catalytic performance in N2 carrier gas is consistent with that of pure silica reported previously [7]. The cyclization of LA to ALs is governed by equilibrium, and it proceeds endothermically. Silica support effectively works as a catalyst for the cyclization. Although there is still a possibility that 2-hydroxypentanoic acid may be another intermediate [30], it is confirmed that ALs would be an intermediate from LA to GVL. Finally, we proposed a speculative model structure of Cu-14Ni/SiO2 catalysts, as shown in Fig. 8 . It is probable that heterogeneous immobilization occurs in NC samples: some of metal nanoparticles in NC sample are bimetallic but other could be single metallic. Namely, the composition of each metal particle would be different. In contrast, citric acid acts as a homogenizer between Cu and Ni and subsequent high dispersion of metal species: homogeneous immobilization of metal species is realized in the CA samples, which have carbon residuals. It is reasonable that the average composition in NC samples is the same as that in CA samples. However, homogeneity of the supported metal species is different each other among the samples. 4 Conclusions In this research, vapor-phase hydrogenation of LA to GVL was performed over bimetallic Cu-Ni/SiO2 prepared by a citric acid-assisted impregnation method. We successfully improved the activity of CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 catalysts and suppressed the deactivation speed during the catalytic reaction in contrast to NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 prepared without using citric acid. XRD patterns and TEM images showed that the dispersion of Cu and Ni on CA-Cu-Ni/SiO2-500 was higher than that of NC-Cu-Ni/SiO2-300 even calcination temperature was different. TG patterns of NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 and CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 showed that carbon originated from citric acid was remained on the CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 calcined at 500 °C. The residual carbon of citric acid probably suppresses the aggregation of metals and forms small Ni and Cu particles. The molar ratio of citric acid/metal at 1 or little higher in an impregnation solution is the best for the hydrogenation of LA to form GVL. In CA-Cu-Ni/SiO2, Cu/Ni weight ratio of 4/16 showed the best catalytic performance for LA to GVL reaction. In a long-run experiment, the deactivation of catalyst due to coke formation could be negligible. The deactivation would be essentially caused by the aggregation of metal species. In addition, possibility of Cu leaching from NC-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2 was indicated by XRF analysis. In CA-6Cu-14Ni/SiO2-500, the Cu leaching would be inhibited by bonding the catalyst surface with carbon residuals originated from citric acid. Appendix A Supplementary data Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.mcat.2018.05.018. coredata.dc:description: Cu-Ni/SiO2 catalyst was developed by impregnation assisted with citric acid for the vapor-phase hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (GVL). The prepared catalysts were characterized by using X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscope (TEM), temperature-programed reduction, thermogravimetry analysis, and X-ray fluorescence analysis. The XRD analysis and the TEM observation of the catalyst samples indicate that the usage of citric acid in the preparation process of impregnation improved the dispersion of Cu and Ni metal on SiO2. A Cu-Ni/SiO2 catalyst with Cu loading of 4 wt.% and Ni of 16 wt.% showed the best performance in the hydrogenation of LA to GVL under ambient H2 pressure at a high weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 13.2 h−1 and 250 °C: the conversion was 98.2% and the GVL selectivity was 97.6%. The catalyst prepared by citric acid-assisted impregnation showed the resistance to catalyst deactivation.
coredata.dc:title: Stable Cu-Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by using citric acid-assisted impregnation for vapor-phase hydrogenation of levulinic acid
